Research Center for Gold Chemistry Tokyo Metropolitan University Tokyo 192-0397 Japan Graphical abstract The selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO) to N2 and H2O at low temperatures was studied to remove low-concentration (50 ppm) NH3 from the air. A series of mordenite (M20)-supported Pt-Au alloy catalysts with different Pt:Au ratios were synthesized and tested in the NH3-SCO. The NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity both depended on the ratio of Pt to Au. The 0.52 wt% Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst showed the highest NH3 conversion (90% at 144 °C) even better than Pt100/M20, which was ascribed to the combination of electron-deficient Pt and electron-rich Au in the alloy nanoparticles. The effects of acid sites on the NH3-SCO were investigated by NaOH treatment of Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst. Results suggested that the acid sites could help to increase NH3 conversion, and that Brønsted acid sites are essential for the selective formation of N2. Keywords NH3-SCO Low-temperature oxidation Pt-Au alloy Electronic structure Acid sites 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is a colorless gas with a characteristic pungent odor. Ammonia emissions are harmful to the environment and have a negative effect on human health, wherein the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract of humans can be easily corroded by ammonia even at low concentrations [1]. In the past few decades, the increasing levels of ammonia pollution caused by the extensive development of agriculture and industry has gradually attracted increasing attention. In comparison with established elimination methods such as adsorption, biofiltration, and catalytic combustion [2–5], the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO) to N2 and H2O at low temperatures is one of the most attractive technologies for the abatement of ammonia pollution because of its harmless products, in addition to various other advantages, including a good safety profile, energy saving characteristics, and a low cost. A number of catalysts have been widely studied for the NH3-SCO, and these can be classified into three main groups based on the catalyst active sites, i.e., supported noble metal catalysts (Pt [6–8], Au [9,10], Pd [11], Ag [12,13]), metal oxide catalysts (MnO2, Co3O4, Fe3O4, NiO, CuO) [14–17], and zeolite-based catalysts (Cu-ZSM-5, Pd-Y, Rh-ZSM-5, Fe-Beta) [18–21]. As would be expected, each group of catalysts has its unique advantages and disadvantages. For example, metal oxide and zeolite-based catalysts exhibit high selectivities toward N2; however, they require significantly higher operating temperatures. In contrast, noble metal catalysts tend to show high activities at relatively low temperatures, but they usually show poor selectivities toward N2. Of the various noble metals, the Pt-based catalysts showed good catalytic activity at relative low temperatures; however, these catalysts still require a temperature of 200 °C to achieve the complete oxidation of NH3 [6,7,22]. In addition, it should be considered that alloy nanoparticles (NPs), which are composed of two or more kinds of metals, may exhibit unique catalytic functions due to their completely different electronic states and structural conformations compared to the original monometallic NPs. For Pt-based alloy catalysts, the metallic Pt with electron-rich state has been considered as the active site for NH3 oxidation, and various studies have been conducted to control the electronic state of Pt by introducing Fe, Cu, and W dopants into Pt-based catalysts to increase the NH3 oxidation activity [6,7,23]. However, the role of electron-deficient Pt on NH3-SCO catalytic performance has never been studied. To obtain a synergistic effect for the NH3-SCO and ultimately yield a higher catalytic activity using lower reaction temperatures, and investigate the electronic effect of Pt on NH3-SCO, the combination of Pt- and Au-based catalysts is an attractive approach. In addition to the electronic state of the noble metal, the acid sites (i.e., the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites) of the catalytic support also significantly affect the catalytic activity and the N2 selectivity [9,24]. Recently, our group reported that the surface Brønsted acid sites on the Au/Nb2O5 catalyst are beneficial for the formation of N2, while the formation of N2O took place on the Lewis acid sites [9,25]. The advantageous effects of the Brønsted acid sites of Nb2O5 in terms of the N2 selectivity were also examined using Pt/Nb2O5 and Pd/Nb2O5 [25]. To verify the role of Brønsted acid sites on other support, and check the influence of acid amount, zeolite was selected here. Thus, with the aim of obtaining a better understanding of the role of Pt-Au alloy and acid sites for the NH3-SCO catalytic performance, we herein report the preparation of a series of Pt-Au alloys supported on mordenite catalysts via the sol immobilization method. The correlation between the NH3-SCO catalytic performance and the structures and electronic states of the Pt-Au alloy catalysts with different Pt:Au ratios are investigated. Results show that the combination of electron-deficient Pt and electron-rich Au could help to increase the NH3 oxidation activity, but decrease the N2 selectivity. The effects of the acid sites, i.e. acid amount and the role of Brønsted acid sites on the mordenite support, are also discussed. Results show the acid sites could help to adsorb NH3 and improve NH3 oxidation activity, and the Brønsted acid sites on the support are beneficial for the formation of N2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of the supported Pt, Au, and Pt-Au alloy catalysts Mordenite 20 (JRC-ZHM20, total surface area: 569 m2 g−1, outer surface area: 15 m2 g−1, SiO2/Al2O3 = 20, abbreviated as M20) was used as the support due to a large amount of acid sites (Table S1). The sol immobilization method was used to deposit Pt, Au, and the Pt-Au alloy on M20 [26,27]. The loading amount of Pt-Au was adjusted to 1 wt% with respect to the M20. Initially, PVP (K15) was added to an aqueous solution containing the desired molar ratios of H2PtCl6·6H2O and HAuCl4·4H2O (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo). After cooling the resulting solution to 0 °C, a 0.1 mol L−1 NaBH4 aqueous solution (NaBH4/metal (mol/mol) = 5) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring at 0 °C. After 0.5 h of colloid generation, M20 (2 g) was added, and the pH was adjusted to 2 using a 1 vol% HCl solution. After vigorous stirring overnight at around 25 °C, the precipitate was separated from the suspension by filtration and thoroughly washed with distilled water (500 mL). The resulting solid was dried at 120 °C and then calcined at 500 °C for 2 h following heating to this target temperature at a rate of 5 °C/min. The obtained catalysts were denoted as PtxAuy/M20, where x and y represent the molar ratio of Pt and Au in alloy NPs, respectively, as determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS). 2.1.2 Modification of the Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst with different ratios of Brønsted:Lewis acid sites To adjust the ratios of the Brønsted to Lewis acid sites of the Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst, the catalyst (0.25 g) was dispersed in NaOH solutions (10 mL) with different concentrations of 0.01, 0.1, and 0.5 M. After stirring for 1 h at around 25 °C, the suspension was filtered, washed with distilled water (500 mL), and dried at 120 °C for 3 h. The resulting samples were denoted as Pt84Au16/M20-XM, where X indicates the NaOH concentration. 2.2 Characterization 2.2.1 Surface area and pore size The specific surface areas and pore sizes of the catalysts were estimated based on data acquired from a N2 adsorption analyzer (BELSORP-mini II-HSP, MicrotracBEL, Osaka, Japan). Before analysis, each sample was evacuated at 300 °C for 3 h. The N2 isotherms obtained at −196 °C were analyzed using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) [28] and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods [29]. The outer surface areas were estimated using the t-plot method [30]. 2.2.2 Atomic absorption spectroscopy Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS, Shimadzu AA-6200) was used to determine the actual loading amounts of Pt and Au on the catalysts. Prior to carrying out the measurements, the sample (10 mg) was dissolved in freshly prepared aqua regia overnight, and then the solution was adjusted to 20 mL using distilled water. Pt and Au solutions of 1.25, 2.5, 5, 10, and 20 mg L−1 were used as standard solutions for the measurements. 2.2.3 High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy The morphologies and sizes of the alloy nanoparticles were investigated using high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM, JEOL, JEM-3200FS) at 300 kV. At least 200 particles were measured in different areas to determine the mean particle diameter and size distribution for each sample. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, 300 kV) was carried out to investigate the dispersions of the Pt and Au atoms in the alloy nanoparticles. 2.2.4 Powder X-ray diffraction The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected using a Rigaku Smartlab with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). XRD data were obtained over the 2θ range from 10 to 80° at a scan rate of 2° min−1. Rigaku Data Analysis Software (PDXL2) was used to identify the positions of the diffraction peaks and the distances of the (111) crystal planes of the PtxAuy alloys to allow calculation of the lattice parameters. 2.2.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using a JEOL JPS-9010 MX instrument with Mg Kα radiation (15 kV, 400 W) in a chamber with a base pressure of ~10−7 Pa. The Pt and Au binding energies were calibrated by adjusting the binding energy of C 1s to 284.8 eV. 2.2.6 X-ray absorption near edge structure analysis X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) experiments for the Au L3-edge and the Pt L3-edge were carried out at the BL01B1 beamline at SPring-8 (Hyogo, Japan) using a Si (311) two-crystal monochromator in fluorescence mode at room temperature. The obtained XANES spectra were analyzed using Athena software (the distance between the pre-edge and the post edge was set to 1 to normalize the samples). 2.2.7 NH3 temperature-programmed desorption The acid properties of the supports were measured by the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) using a Belcat system equipped with a mass spectrometer detector (BEL Japan). Before carrying out the measurements, the sample (~40 mg) was preheated in helium (30 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, ammonia (5% NH3/He) was introduced at 100 °C for 20 min, and then He was allowed to flow through the system for 30 min. Finally, the desorption profile was recorded from 100 to 700 °C using a mass spectrometer under a flow of helium (30 mL min−1). 2.2.8 Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy The pyridine adsorption experiments were carried out on an FT/IR-6100 JASCO spectrometer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from 1400 to 1700 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Initially, the sample (10 mg) was pressed into a self-supported wafer with a diameter of 10 mm. The wafer was then placed in a quartz IR cell, which was sealed with CaF2 windows and connected to a vacuum system. The pretreatment procedure was carried out at 500 °C at a ramp of 10 °C min−1 for 90 min in a 40 kPa O2 atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, 0.40 kPa pyridine vapor was introduced into the system for 30 min. After adsorption, the sample was heated to 150 °C for 60 min to reduce the physical desorption of pyridine. Finally, the pyridine chemical absorption spectrum was recorded for each sample. All spectra were recorded by accumulating 32 scans. 2.2.9 In situ NH3-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy The NH3-SCO reaction mechanism was investigated by in situ NH3-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (NH3-DRIFTS) on an FT/IR-6100 JASCO spectrometer equipped with a liquid N2-cooled mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. Initially, the sample (~20 mg) was transferred to the sample holder and cell. Subsequently, the sample was pretreated at 250 °C for 1 h under N2 at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1 to remove any adsorbed water and impurities. The background was taken at desired measurement temperature before NH3 adsorption. All spectra were recorded by accumulating 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.3 The NH3-SCO reaction The catalysts (150 mg) were tested for the NH3-SCO reaction in a fixed-bed flow reactor (7.9 mm) using the Belcat II system under atmospheric pressure. The composition of the gas mixture at the reactor inlet was NH3 (100 ppm, 50 mL min−1), O2 (20 mL min−1), and Ar (30 mL min−1). The total flow rate of the reaction mixture was 100 mL min−1 with a space velocity (SV) of 40,000 mL h−1g−1. The catalysts were fully adsorbed by NH3 and O2 at twice the reaction flow rate for 24 h at 30 °C, and then the reaction temperature was increased to the desired temperature at a rate of 1 °C min−1 and allowed to stand for 8 h to obtain the data in a stable state. The outlet gas compositions were analyzed using an online FT-IR spectrometer (JASCO, FT-IR4700) equipped with a triglycine sulfate (TGS) detector. The NH3 conversion and the N2 selectivity were calculated as follows: N H 3 c o n v e r s i o n % = N H 3 i n - N H 3 o u t N H 3 i n × 100 % N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y % = N H 3 i n - N H 3 o u t - N O o u t - N O 2 o u t - 2 N 2 O o u t N H 3 i n - N H 3 o u t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Characterization of the PtxAuy alloy catalysts A series of PtxAuy/M20 catalysts were synthesized using the sol immobilization method. Table 1 lists the loading amounts of the different PtxAuy/M20 catalysts. The obtained Pt-Au loading amount is 0.39–0.66 wt%, and the proportion of Pt in alloy NPs gradually decreases with the increase in Au amount. Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of the M20, Au100/M20, Pt84Au16/M20, and Pt100/M20 species. No structural changes were observed upon the deposition of Pt-Au alloy NPs on the M20 support (PDF No. 98841). Fig. 1B shows the magnified XRD patterns of the M20, Au100/M20, Pt100/M20, and various PtxAuy/M20 catalysts. In the patterns of the Pt100/M20 and Au100/M20 monometallic catalysts, the diffraction peaks attributed to Pt (111) and Au (111) appeared at 2θ = 39.6 and 38.1°, respectively. In the patterns of the Pt-Au alloy catalysts, some peaks appeared between the two original peaks. However, it was difficult to determine their peak positions because of their low intensities and overlapping with the peaks of M20 (2θ = 39.04° (731), 39.27° (172), 39.51° (570), and 39.74° (800)). For Pt17Au83/M20 and Pt30Au70/M20, weak peaks were observed between 2θ = 39.6 and 38.1°, suggesting the formation of small Pt-Au alloy NPs. To avoid overlapping of the diffraction peaks attributed to the support, SiO2-supported PtxAuy catalysts with different Pt/Au ratios were prepared by the sol immobilization method. In the patterns obtained for the SiO2-supported Pt and Au monometallic catalysts, the diffraction peaks attributed to Pt (111) and Au (111) clearly appeared at 2θ = 39.6 and 38.1°, respectively. The peaks appeared between the two original peaks (Fig. 1C and S1) and shifted to higher angles with an increase in the Pt atomic ratio in alloy NPs. Fig. 2 shows the plots of the lattice parameters for the PtxAuy/silica alloy NPs (estimated from the XRD diffraction patterns of the (111) crystal phases) as a function of the Pt ratio in the Pt-Au NPs, as determined by AAS. The straight lines drawn in Fig. 2 represent the theoretical relationship between the lattice parameter and the Pt:Au ratio according to Vegard’s law [31]. As shown, the lattice parameters of the PtxAuy/silica alloy NPs decreased as the Pt content in the alloy NPs increased, and the trend closely followed the theoretical line. These results indicate that the two different metals composing the Pt-Au alloy NPs were homogeneously mixed to form random alloys with a face-centered cubic (FCC) structure. However, due to the overlap with the mordenite support at 2θ ≈ 39.6°, the lattice parameters of PtxAuy/M20 could not be accurately calculated, with the exception of the case of the Au-dominated alloy NPs. Therefore, only three parameters were calculated for the M20-supported PtxAuy catalysts (Au100/M20, Pt17Au83/M20, and Pt30Au70/M20), and these are shown as red dots in Fig. 2. These plots for the M20-supported alloy catalysts also closely followed the theoretical line, also suggesting the formation of homogeneously mixed alloys. The morphologies of the Pt–Au alloy NPs were identified by TEM. More specifically, the HAADF-STEM images and the size distribution histograms for the M20-supported Pt–Au alloy catalysts containing a series of Pt:Au ratios are shown in Fig. 3 . As shown, the average size of the Pt NPs on Pt100/M20 was 5.0 nm (Fig. 3a) while the average size of the Au NPs on Au100/M20 was 19.4 nm (Fig. 3h). Well-dispersed Pt–Au alloy NPs with average diameters ranging from 5.8 to 8.4 nm were found on PtxAuy/M20 (Fig. 3b–g), although a small fraction of alloy nanoparticles larger than 10 nm was also observed. The average pore size, BET surface area, and outer surface area of M20 were determined to be 0.64 nm, 569 m2 g−1, and 15 m2 g−1, respectively, thereby indicating that the Pt-Au alloy NPs were generally larger than the average pore diameter of M20, suggesting that the Pt-Au alloy NPs were dispersed on the outer surface of M20. EDS was then used to investigate the distributions of Pt and Au on the Pt84Au16/M20 and Pt65Au35/M20 catalysts. Fig. S2 shows the EDS line scans and mapping images of Pt84Au16/M20 and Pt65Au35/M20. From the results of the EDS line scan over one single alloy NPs, and mapping images of various alloy NPs, both Pt and Au signals appeared obviously. It was apparent that the Pt and Au atoms were well dispersed, and that each nanoparticle contained both Pt and Au. CO adsorption experiments were then carried out to determine the amount of surface Pt on the PtxAuy alloys [32]. As shown in Table S2, the amount of adsorbed CO decreased upon increasing the Au content in the PtxAuy alloys, suggesting that the surface Pt amount decreased when the Au ratio increased. This result implies that the surface configuration of Pt and Au atoms of PtxAuy alloy changed with different Pt and Au ratios. Considering the XRD, HAADF-STEM, EDS, and CO adsorption results for PtxAuy/M20, it was clear that well-dispersed Pt and Au formed Pt-Au alloy NPs on the outer surface of the M20 support. 3.1.2 Electronic states of Pt and Au XPS measurements were used to investigate the electronic states of Pt and Au in the PtxAuy/M20 catalysts. Thus, Fig. 4 shows the Au 4f XPS profiles of the PtxAuy/M20 catalysts containing a series of Pt:Au atomic ratios. In particular, the binding energy peaks of Au 4f 7/2 and 4f 5/2 on Au100/M20 appeared at 84.1 and 87.6 eV, respectively (Fig. 4g). Upon increasing the Pt content to give PtxAuy/M20, the binding energies of Au 4f 7/2 and 4f 5/2 gradually shifted to lower values, indicating that the Au atoms existed in a more electron-rich environment when the Pt content was increased. This result clearly indicates that electron transfer occurs from the Pt atoms to the Au atoms when they form an alloy. This electron transfer is consistent with the Pauling electronegativity of Au (2.54) relative to Pt (2.20), resulting in an electron-deficient Pt and an electron-rich Au in the PtxAuy alloy nanoparticles [33–35]. To obtain further insight into the local structures and electronic states of Pt and Au in PtxAuy/M20 catalysts, a series of Pt-Au alloy catalysts were characterized by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). The normalized Au L 3-edge and Pt L 3-edge XANES spectra of the PtxAuy/M20 catalysts, the references of the Pt foil, and Au foil were recorded, and are shown in Fig. 5 . The shape of XANES spectra and absorption edge energies of Pt and Au in Pt-Au alloys were similar to those of Pt foil and Au foil regardless of Pt:Au ratios, respectively, thereby suggesting that the Pt and Au species of PtxAuy/M20 were present in the metallic state. Fig. 6 shows plots of white line intensities in the Pt and Au L 3-edges XANES results as a function of the Au content. The intensity of the white line is attributed to the electronic transitions from the 2p3/2 core-level states, which directly reflect the electronic states of the vacant d orbitals of the metal particles. The L 3-edge reflects the final vacant d states of both the 5d3/2 and 5d5/2 levels [36]. As can be seen, upon increasing the Au content, the heights of the white lines in the Pt L 3-edges gradually reduced, whereas those in Au L 3-edges increased. The decreasing tendency of the Pt L 3-edge white line intensity was therefore related to the increase in that of the Au L 3-edge as the Au content increased from y = 16 to 83 in PtxAuy/M20 [37]. The intensities of the Pt white lines at 11.5625 keV were higher for all PtxAuy/M20 catalysts than for the Pt foil, suggesting that Pt is in an electron-deficient state in the alloy catalysts. Moreover, the white line intensity of the PtxAuy/M20 alloy catalysts appeared at 11.921 keV, which was lower than that of the Au foil, suggesting the existence of electron-rich Au species. These results further verified the electron transfer from Pt to Au in the PtxAuy alloy, which is consistent with the results obtained from XPS measurements. Based on the above characterization, it was apparent that homogeneously mixed Pt-Au nanoalloys were successfully synthesized. Moreover, our results indicated that the electronic states of Pt and Au can be adjusted by changing the Pt:Au ratio of the nanoalloy. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Effect of the Pt-Au alloy on the NH3-SCO Fig. 7 A show the relationship between the NH3 conversion and the reaction temperature over the PtxAuy alloy catalysts, and the magnification area from 100 to 180 °C is shown in Fig. 7B. As shown in Fig. 7A, Au100/M20 exhibited the lowest catalytic activity but gave a full NH3 conversion at 300 °C. Compared with Au100/M20, Pt100/M20 showed a significantly higher catalytic activity, with full NH3 conversion being reached at ~170 °C. In addition, the catalytic activity of PtxAuy/M20 increased upon increasing the Pt:Au ratio. Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 7B, Pt84Au16/M20 showed a higher NH3 conversion than Pt100/M20 at all tested temperatures up to 160 °C, and Pt77Au23/M20 also showed a higher NH3 conversion than Pt100/M20 in the range of NH3 conversion >60%. In addition, Pt72Au28/M20 and Pt65Au35/M20 showed NH3 conversions comparable to that of Pt100/M20. Comparisons of the reported catalytic performances of the Pt- and/or Au-based catalysts are listed in Table S3. Our PtxAuy/M20 catalysts exhibited higher NH3 oxidation activities at low temperatures compared to previously reported systems, although we do note that there were differences in experimental conditions. Fig. 7C shows the effects of the Pt:Au ratio on the temperature required to achieve an NH3 conversion of 90%. More specifically, for Pt100/M20, a temperature of 157 °C was required, while for Au100/M20, 90% conversion was reached at 293 °C; this resulted in a volcano-like relationship between the temperature of 90% NH3 conversion and the Pt:Au ratio. In addition, the NH3 conversions of both Pt84Au16/M20 and Pt77Au23/M20 were high, 90% NH3 conversion was achieved to ~145 °C in both cases, which suggests that the Pt-Au alloy has a positive effect on NH3 conversion when the fraction of Au is small (i.e., up to 20%). The improved conversion for the NH3 oxidation process that was observed due to alloying can also been seen from the calculated TOFs (Fig. 7D and Table 2 ). The reaction rates of various catalysts at 125 °C were examined to compare the TOF value. For the TOF calculations, an NH3 conversion of <20% was employed, which was based on a controlling total flow rate. The TOF values were calculated based on the amount of Pt atoms on the Pt-Au alloy surface, as measured by CO pulse chemisorption experiments (Table S1). As shown in Fig. 7D, the calculation of the TOF values for Au100/M20 and Pt17Au83/M20 was difficult due to their low catalytic activities compared to the other catalysts. In contrast, the TOF value of Pt100/M20 was 0.28 h−1; however, those of the Pt84Au16/M20 Pt77Au23/M20, Pt72Au28/M20, Pt65Au35/M20, and Pt30Au70/M20 were significantly higher than that of Pt100/M20. Among them, Pt30Au70/M20 showed the highest TOF of 2.65 h−1. In general, the tendency of the plot indicates that the maximum TOF was achieved with Pt ratios ranging from 30 to 65%, where well-dispersed Pt and Au atoms were present in the Pt-Au alloy. Since similar total amounts of Au and Pt were used in the reaction, the temperature required to achieve 90% conversion using the Pt84Au16/M20 and Pt77Au23/M20 catalysts resulted in a higher catalytic activity (Fig. 7C). These results further suggested that an improved NH3 oxidation activity was achieved over a Pt-Au alloy surface, and so our observations contributed to explaining the phenomena of improved NH3 catalytic activities over the Pt84Au16/M20 and Pt77Au23/M20 catalysts compared to Pt100/M20. Fig. 8 A and B show the relationship between the NH3 conversion and the N2 selectivity over the PtxAuy alloy catalysts. As shown, the N2 selectivity decreased with increasing NH3 conversion due to the formation of N2O as a by-product, regardless of the Pt:Au ratio. No other products were detected. Au100/M20 showed the highest N2 selectivity, which gave a 90 % N2 selectivity at 90 % NH3 conversion. Pt100/M20 showed a lower N2 selectivity than Au100/M20, i.e., 68 % N2 selectivity at a full NH3 conversion (Fig. 8A). In addition, Fig. 8C shows the effects of the Pt:Au ratio on the selectivity at 90% NH3 conversion. As indicated, the majority of PtxAuy/M20 catalysts showed higher N2O selectivity at high NH3 conversions of ~90% compared to those achieved using Pt100/M20 and Au100/M20. This result suggests that the formation of Pt-Au alloy helps to increase the amount of N2O by-product produced during the NH3 oxidation, compared with monometallic catalysts. To gain insight into the reaction mechanism, kinetic studies (i.e., determination of the reaction orders with respect to NH3 and O2) were carried out at the desired temperature, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 2. As can be seen, the values of n (NH3) were significantly larger than those of n (O2) over all catalysts, with the exception of the Au-dominated catalysts (Pt17Au83/M20 and Au100/M20). These results indicate that the rate-determining step of the NH3-SCO process over the PtxAuy/M20 catalysts (with the exception of Pt17Au83/M20 and Au100/M20) relates to NH3 adsorption and activation, rather than the activation of O2. Moreover, the reaction order of NH3 increased from 0.51 (for Pt100/M20) to 1.16 (for Pt65Au35/M20) and then decreased to 0.94 (for Pt30Au70/M20). The maximum of n (NH3) was obtained for Pt65Au35/M20, where the Pt and Au atoms were well-dispersed in the alloy. In addition, it was also found that the reaction order of O2 gradually increased upon increasing the Au ratio in the alloy NPs, thereby indicating the enhanced adsorption of O2 over Pt compared to over the Au surface, which is beneficial for the activation of NH3 over the alloy surface. These reaction order investigations suggest that the activation of NH3 is easier over well-dispersed Pt and Au interfaces, which is consistent with the TOF results. 3.2.2 Effects of the support acid sites on the NH3-SCO To examine the effects of the acid sites on the NH3-SCO catalytic performance, Pt84Au16/M20 was treated with NaOH as a base to neutralize both the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (Scheme S1). Fig. 10 shows the pyridine-adsorbed IR spectra of Pt84Au16/M20 treated with different concentrations of NaOH aqueous solution. As can be seen in the figure, the areas of the bands corresponding to pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (1545 cm−1) and Lewis acid sites (1445 cm−1) decreased upon increasing the concentration of the NaOH solution, indicating a decrease in the number of total acid sites (B + L). Table 3 lists the normalized acid amounts of the Pt84Au16/M20-XM catalysts, wherein it is apparent that the total acid amount and the Brønsted and Lewis acid site ratios (B/L ratio) of the Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst were altered by varying the concentration of NaOH (Fig. 10d and Table 3). Fig. 11 shows the effects of the acid properties (i.e., the B + L and the B/L ratio) on the NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity over Pt84Au16/M20 treated with NaOH. As shown in Fig. 11A, the NH3 conversions gradually decreased with a decrease in the number of acid sites at high temperatures (>160 °C). The corresponding relationships between the temperatures at NH3 conversions of 50, 70, and 90% and the total amount of acid sites (B + L) are shown in Fig. 11C. A clear increase in the reaction temperature was required to achieve 70 and 90% NH3 conversion levels with a decreasing value of B + L, which strongly suggests that the acid sites play an important role in accelerating the NH3 oxidation process. Fig. 11B shows the relationship between the NH3 conversion and the N2 selectivity over Pt84Au16/M20 treated with NaOH. The corresponding relationships between the N2 selectivities at NH3 conversions of 50, 70, and 90% and the B/L ratio are shown in Fig. 11d. As indicated, the N2 selectivity significantly decreased upon decreasing the B/L ratio, indicating that the Brønsted acid sites play an important role in N2 formation in the NH3-SCO process. These results are consistent with those of previous reports [9]. 3.3 Reaction mechanism To clarify the reaction mechanism of the NH3-SCO process, the FT-IR spectra of the Pt100/M20 and Pt84Au16/M20 catalysts during the reaction were recorded using an in situ DRIFTS cell at 250 °C (Fig. 12 ), 130 °C, and 190 °C (Fig. S3). After treatment with a 5 vol% NH3/He flow, a negative band appeared at 3652 cm−1, which could be assigned to the stretching modes of the isolated surface hydroxyl groups (Brønsted acid sites (Si(OH)Al)) [39,40], on which NH3 was adsorbed. Bands at 3411, 3394, and 3352 cm−1 corresponding to the N-H stretching vibration of NH4 + were also observed [41,42]. Furthermore, the bands observed in the range of 3000–2200 cm−1 were considered to be attributed to the OH stretching vibrations of water adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites of the zeolite [43,44], while the two bands in the 2250–1750 cm−1 range were attributed to the combination mode between the bending and the highest frequency frustrated rotation of NH4 + [45]. In addition, the bands at 3331 and 1624 cm−1 were assigned to the gas phase NH3, while those at 1736 and 1525 cm−1 arose from the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites, respectively [20]. Following the adsorption of NH3, the NH3/He gas flow was switched to O2, and it was found that the bands related to the NH3 adsorbed on the acid sites (i.e., at 1736 and 1525 cm−1) and those corresponding to the N-H vibration modes (i.e., at 3411, 3394, and 3352 cm−1) gradually decreased in intensity. Moreover, the negative band at 3652 cm−1 was weakened, indicating that the adsorbed NH4 + species reacted with O2. On the other hand, the bands attributed to gas-phase N2O (2237 and 2210 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1300 cm−1), and bridged bidentate nitrate (1270 cm−1) were clearly observed, before eventually disappearing. These adsorbed species were therefore considered to be reaction intermediates. It should be noted that these intermediates were observed at 190 °C (Fig. S3B and D) but not at 130 °C (Fig. S3A and C). Nitrate species, which are the most important intermediates in the internal selective catalytic reduction (i-SCR) mechanism, were observed for both the Pt100/M20 and Pt84Au16/M20 catalysts. It is, therefore, reasonable to speculate that the NH3-SCO process taking place over both the Pt100/M20 and PtxAuy/M20 catalysts proceeded via the i-SCR reaction mechanism as follows [12,46]: (1) 4NH3 + 5O2 → 4NO + 6H2O (2) 4NO + 4NH3 + O2 → 4 N2 + 6H2O (3) 4NO + 4NH3 + 3O2 → 4N2O + 6H2 On the other hand, the PtxAuy alloy catalysts exhibited higher activities in the NH3-SCO than Pt100/M20. Moreover, the activity of Pt84Au16/M20 decreased with a decrease in the number of acid sites and the B/L ratio. These results strongly suggest that both the electronic state of the Pt-Au alloy NPs and the acid properties (i.e., the number of acid sites and the B/L ratio) affect the catalytic activity of the NH3-SCO reaction. A possible reaction mechanism to account for the alloying effect and the acid site effect is shown in Scheme 1 . As shown in Scheme 1, over the bare Pt surface, NH3 and O2 are dissociatively adsorbed on the Pt atoms due to the electronic attraction of Pt [step (1)]. Subsequently, O2 can dissociate to active O on or around the Pt surface. Simultaneously, the H atom in NH3 can be easily stripped by the O atom to form the adsorbed amide (–NH2), imide (–NH), and hydroxyl species. In addition, water can be formed through the reaction of two hydroxyl groups [step (2)]. Adsorbed nitrate species can then be formed due to further oxidation on the Pt surface [step (3)]. Finally, N2O and N2 can be formed and desorbed from the Pt surface with the help of NH3 through the i-SCR reaction pathway [step (4)]. Moreover, the NH3 oxidation activity and selectivity toward N2O over the PtxAuy alloy surface were enhanced due to the distinct structural composition and electronic structure of the Pt-Au alloy. More specifically, NH3 could more easily and strongly adsorb onto the electron-deficient Pt atoms than onto the bare Pt surface due to the electronic attraction between the lone electron pair of NH3 and the electron-deficient Pt, ultimately resulting in an improved adsorption concentration of NH3 on the PtxAuy surface [step (1)]. In addition, the molecular O2 is likely to be captured by an electronic attraction, leading to the production of an active O species [47]; this activated O species is more likely to be immobilized and stabilized by the electron-rich Au through electronic attractions, resulting in a higher concentration of activated O-containing species on the PtxAuy surface [step (2)]. Subsequently, a greater quantity of adsorbed nitrate species could be formed around the alloy interface via i-SCR reaction pathways due to the higher concentration of O-containing and N-containing species [step (3)]. Finally, greater quantities of N2 and N2O can be formed around the alloy interface compared with the bare Pt surface through the same i-SCR reaction pathways mentioned above [step (4)]. On the other hand, the Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites present on the zeolite surface could help to adsorb NH3 and participate in the oxidation reaction via different reaction pathways, thereby increasing the catalytic activities of the catalysts. In addition, the N2 selectivity decreased gradually with a decrease in the B/L ratio, which strongly suggested that the Brønsted acid sites were helpful for the formation of N2, wherein N2H4 is regarded as a possible reaction intermediate [9,25]. Following NaOH treatment, the surface Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites can be blocked by Na+, thereby inhibiting the adsorption of NH3 and decreasing the NH3 concentration on the catalyst surface. As a result, the NH3 oxidation activity and the N2 selectivity decrease due to inhibition by N2H4 and the i-SCR reaction pathway, respectively. 4 Conclusion Mordenite-supported PtxAuy alloy catalysts containing different Pt and Au ratios were synthesized for application in the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO). The effect of the Pt-Au alloy and the surface acid sites of the mordenite support were investigated. It was found that NH3-SCO catalytic performance is strongly dependent on the Pt:Au ratio of the Pt-Au alloy and the combination of electron-deficient Pt and electron-rich Au helped to increase the NH3 oxidation activity but decrease the N2 selectivity during NH3-SCO. Different reaction pathways were proposed for the pure Pt and PtxAuy alloy surfaces based on the distinguished electronic states. In comparison with the pure Pt surface, the PtxAuy alloy surface was found to contribute to an increase in the concentrations of O- and N-containing species around the Pt-Au interface through the combination of electron-deficient Pt and electron-rich Au, thereby leading to improved NH3 conversion and a decreased N2 selectivity. Moreover, the role of acid sites on the mordenite support in increasing the NH3 oxidation activity, and the role of Brønsted acid sites in promoting the formation of N2 were both verified. This study firstly report the effects of the electronic states of PtxAuy on the NH3 oxidation reaction pathway, and so is expected to contribute to a comprehensive understanding from an electronic perspective. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO) to N2 and H2O at low temperatures was studied to remove low-concentration (50 ppm) NH3 from the air. A series of mordenite (M20)-supported Pt-Au alloy catalysts with different Pt:Au ratios were synthesized and tested in the NH3-SCO. The NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity both depended on the ratio of Pt to Au. The 0.52 wt% Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst showed the highest NH3 conversion (90% at 144 °C) even better than Pt100/M20, which was ascribed to the combination of electron-deficient Pt and electron-rich Au in the alloy nanoparticles. The effects of acid sites on the NH3-SCO were investigated by NaOH treatment of Pt84Au16/M20 catalyst. Results suggested that the acid sites could help to increase NH3 conversion, and that Brønsted acid sites are essential for the selective formation of N2.
coredata.dc:title: Selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen over zeolite-supported Pt-Au catalysts: Effects of alloy formation and acid sites
